Award.AwardTitle: Formative Assessment in Mathematics: Current Status and Guidelines for Future Developments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In response to the increased use of formative assessment practices in California's PK-12 mathematics classrooms, the University of California-Davis and Claremont Graduate University join efforts to investigate what formative assessments are in use, how practitioners and students are utilizing these assessments, and how they impact performance on summative state assessments. Four research questions guide this study: (1) What is the current status of formative assessment use in California's PK & K, elementary, middle, and high schools? (2) What are the content and psychometric properties of the current formative assessments? (3) What impact do formative assessment outcomes have on student academic achievement as measured by summative assessments? and (4) Does the use of formative assessment differentially impact performance of subgroups of students, such as ELLs, students of color, economically disadvantaged students, and students with disabilities?

The study consists of three phases and employs a mixed-methods approach to answer the four research questions. To answer research question 1, Phase I administers an online survey to all school principals in three major regions of the State (northern, central, and southern). Frequency and descriptive analyses of data are conducted to obtain an accurate view of the current status of formative assessments. Software is used to qualitatively analyze responses to open-ended questions. Frequencies of categorical responses and mean and standard deviations of Likert-type responses are compared across respondents with different backgrounds and schools with different characteristics. To address research question 2, Phase II conducts a series of psychometric and content analyses of existing assessments to ascertain validity, reliability, and accessibility of assessments. A total of 120 PK-12 schools with the strongest formative assessment instruments and the greatest formative assessment impact on summative assessments participate in these analyses. Sample sizes for this phase, representative of a four-grade span (PK & K, 4th, 8th, and 10th grades), were determined through a power analysis for a minimum of 0.25 standard deviation detectable difference with a statistical power of 80% at a 0.05 type I error. Due to the study's focus on traditionally low-performing and underrepresented populations, a stratified random sampling approach in which subgroup identifiers are used as stratification variables is employed. To assess content properties, the study utilizes Webb's (1997) alignment methodology. Reliability of formative assessments is examined using the internal consistency approach (Cronbach alpha). Validity is analyzed through content- and criterion-related validity approaches, including a Multi-Traits/Multi-Methods approach. To answer research questions 3 and 4, a series of path models are created to explore the power of formative assessments in predicting student performance on the State's end-of-year assessments. In addition, an Ex Post Facto design is conducted to investigate whether one or more preexisting conditions have possibly caused subsequent differences in the groups of participants. To document successful practices, the study's Phase III develops case studies of six schools with effective formative assessment practices and demonstrated academic growth using summative measures. Case studies include audiotaped focus group interviews with teachers and administrators, videotaped observations of teacher meetings, and classroom observations.

The main outcome of this study will be a set of research-informed and field-tested conclusions, recommendations, guidelines, and tools for the development and use of new or improved PK-12 mathematics formative assessments. Outcome tools include a blueprint and test specifications based on the California State Mathematics Content Standards for 8th grade, and a field-tested formative assessment prototype focused on key algebra concepts and skills for that grade level. The Center for the Study of Evaluation at the University of California-Los Angeles serves as the project external evaluator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of the Formative Assessment in Mathematics (FAM) project is to present an overall picture of FAM around the nation by exploring the current status of FAM in Kindergarten through Grade 12 (K-12), developing and providing an operational definition of FAM, and implementing professional development (PD) models that can guide FAM in K-12 classrooms. For this project brief, we focused on the impact of two interventions using PD models for FAM on student learning, which were created based on a formative assessment prototype system we developed, the Universe of Formative Assessment Components (UFAC). More details about UFAC can be found on our project website, listed below.

For the UC Davis FAM intervention, we recruited a total of 24 teachers (17 treatment teachers and 7 control teachers) across 18 California school districts. Students’ developing skills were measured through five formal assessments as they progressed through two units of Common Core State Standards in Grade 8 Mathematics for Expressions and Equations: 8.EE5&6 (56) and 8.EE.7 (7). All students were administered a pre-test. Partway through the unit, treatment students took an interim assessment. Based on the results of the interim assessment, treatment teachers were asked to analyze students’ understanding of concepts and to make further adjustments to their instruction based on their students’ needs. Treatment teachers were trained on how to use the provided scoring tool and were encouraged to instruct students in flexible ability groups. At the end of the unit, students’ understanding of the standards in that unit were assessed through a post-test for that unit. Teachers participating in both units of our study would repeat the process for the second unit minus the pre-test.

The effect of the UC Davis FAM intervention on 8th-grade students’ performance was significant for one unit (56), but not the other (7). The students in the treatment group performed higher than their peers in the control group on post-test 56 even after controlling for pretest scores. However, the pre-test was also found to highly covariate with the post-test 56 score, which might explain why students did not achieve comparable results for post-test 7. We believe that the positive effects of the UC Davis intervention are mainly due to our UFAC system as mentioned briefly above. In addition to summative assessment, the key components of the UFAC system could guide teachers’ implementation of FAM-based teaching resources. During the intervention, the recruited treatment teachers could set up learning goals with exercises and activities that were well-organized, sequenced, and clear in their purposes through the UFAC system. 

For the UCLA FAM intervention, we recruited a total of 11 teachers (5 treatment teachers and 6 control teachers) from two Southern California school districts. The purpose of this intervention was to examine the effects of prototype FAM tasks on student learning and attitudes; these tasks were designed to engage students in mathematical reasoning and support teachers’ analysis of student understanding when teaching a unit coving 8.EE5&6. The study also solicited teachers’ perspectives on the implementation and value of the tools and their suggestions for improvement. Treatment teachers also participated in PD that focused on formative assessment research, the targeted math standards, and overall FAM task design.

Overall, treatment teachers generally agreed that the formative tasks proved useful.  and that the formative assessments they had implemented fit well with their unit of instruction and revealed students’ misconceptions. Most of the treatment teachers agreed that they had adjusted their instruction to meet the needs of individual students based on information collected via the tasks, although teachers did not feel as though they had adequate time to plan for the FAM tasks. Analyses also revealed that the tasks were generally difficult for students. Students experienced the most challenge in providing mathematical explanations. However, students’ responses to the tasks did provide diagnostic information concerning their thinking and reasoning and appeared to illuminate student understandings and misconceptions around the target concepts. A key component of each task involved students rating their current understanding of concepts covered. However, students seemed to vary in the accuracy of their self-assessments. Students’ self-reflections tended to be less aligned with a performance for those who weren’t as successful. Students rarely chose the “thumbs down” option, even when struggling.

We have also created a project website that includes all the relevant project documents including original proposals, annual reports, reports of TAC meetings and TAC’s suggestions. The website also includes data related to the FAM intervention (data and instruments), and correspondence with different organizations including IES. Conference posters and papers can also be found on the website. Please visit the project website at http://www.famproject.net.
